Welcome to the Darden Fiscal 2016 Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, please disconnect at this time. 
I will now turn the call over to Mr. Kevin Kalicak. Thank you. You may begin.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Maddie. Good morning, and welcome, everyone. With me today is Gene Lee, Darden's CEO; and RIck Cardenas, CFO. As a reminder, comments made during this call will include forward-looking statements, as defined in the Private Securities Litigation
componenttext:
Thank you, Maddie. Good morning, and welcome, everyone. With me today is Gene Lee, Darden's CEO; and RIck Cardenas, CFO. As a reminder, comments made during this call will include forward-looking statements, as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations and projections. Those risks are described in the company's press release, which was distributed earlier today and its filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. We are simultaneously broadcasting a presentation during this call, which is posted in the Investor Relations section of our website, at www.darden.com. 
Today's discussion and presentation includes certain non-GAAP measurements and a reconciliation of these measurements is included in the presentation. We plan to release fiscal 2017 first quarter earnings on October 4, before the market opens, followed by a conference call. 
This morning, Gene will share some brief remarks about quarterly performance and brand highlights. Rick will then provide more detail on our financial results from the fourth quarter and share our outlook for fiscal 2017 and Gene will have some closing remarks before we open the call for your questions. 
Before we begin, I want to point out that just as we did last quarter, we reported same-restaurant sales on both the fiscal and comparable calendar basis. This morning, we will refer to the comparable calendar comps during our remarks, unless otherwise noted. Additionally, sales and earnings comparisons versus last year will exclude the impact of the 53rd week in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2015, unless otherwise noted. 
Now, I'll turn the call over to Gene.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. We had a strong quarter with each of our brand significantly outperforming the industry benchmarks as we continue to focus on improving our execution. Same-restaurant sales grew 2.6% wit
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. We had a strong quarter with each of our brand significantly outperforming the industry benchmarks as we continue to focus on improving our execution. Same-restaurant sales grew 2.6% with positive same-restaurant sales in each of our brands. 
It was a volatile quarter as results of multiple holiday and calendar shifts, including Easter, Memorial Day and spring break vacations, which we believe negatively impacted comps across the industry. 
Olive Garden had another great quarter and concluded a year in which we serve more than 220 million guests. The Olive Garden brand is extremely relevant, the business is strong and our strategy continues to deliver results as evidenced by our ongoing momentum. 
In Q4, same-restaurant sales grew 2.4%, outperforming the industry benchmarks, excluding Darden, by more than 440 basis points in both sales and traffic. This was our seventh consecutive quarter same-restaurant sales growth and fourth consecutive quarter of positive same-restaurant guest counts. 
3 key drivers of this performance include: First, further simplification of our operational processes and procedures, leading to improved execution in our restaurants; second, culinary innovation that builds on the brand equities and flavor profiles that our loyal guests enjoy most as seen with our successful Italian pot pies, Mediterranean fresh and lasagna lover promotions; and finally, continued growth of our successful OG To Go platform. 
To Go sales were up 19% year-over-year with a 2-year growth rate over 40%. For the year, OG To Go sales represented 10.8% of total sales, an increase of 140 basis points versus last year. Additionally, we have the best Mother's Day in Olive Garden history, which further demonstrates the brand's relevance and its broader appeal as a destination for family celebrating time together. 
Olive Garden remains laser-focused on driving frequency of our loyal guests, while delivering great experiences and our guests are responding positively. Our innovation pipeline is strong and we still have meaningful operations improvements to capture. 
LongHorn Steakhouse maintained its solid top line momentum and once again delivered strong profit growth. Same-restaurant sales grew 2.2% to 13 consecutive quarters of growth, outperforming the industry benchmarks, excluding Darden, by more than 400 basis points and same-restaurant traffic was well above the industry average. 
We will continue to invest in food quality to enhance the overall perceived value of the dining experience and have multiple in-restaurant test underway. 
Additionally, LongHorn continues to simplify operations to strengthen in-restaurant execution and delivered great guest experiences. This focus on operational excellence is augmented by compelling, nonprice pointed promotions like our big bold stakes and LongHorn favorites that reinforce our steak expertise. 
Looking at our specialty restaurants. All 5 businesses continue to deliver solid results that include a positive same-restaurant sales growth at each, led by Seasons 52 at 5% and Bahama Breeze at 4.7%. 
Seasons 52 had another strong quarter. We continue to execute our strategy at a very high level and are impressed with what the team has been able to achieve throughout the year. Seasons 52 is an on-trend concept, giving guests the opportunity to enjoy handcrafted cuisine that is healthful without sacrificing the taste or style. We look forward to building on the momentum we have created as we rebuild the pipeline for value-creating new restaurants. 
Yard House represents a significant growth opportunity for us. And during the quarter, we named Mike Night our president. I'm excited to have Mike lead the Yard House team and he is supported by an extremely strong team. Mike did a tremendous job leading Bahama Breeze, delivering same-restaurant sales growth of 3.5% annually over the past 3 years, and I'm confident he will build on the momentum at Yard House. 
All of our specialty restaurants continue to perform well and are differentiated and well positioned to grow market share into the future. Overall, I'm pleased with the results we achieve this quarter. 
And now, I'll turn it over to Rick to discuss those in more detail.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gene, and good morning, everyone. Darden's fourth quarter diluted net earnings per share from continuing operations were $1.10, both on a reported and adjusted basis. They were 8.9% higher than last year's adjusted diluted net earnings per shar
componenttext:
Thank you, Gene, and good morning, everyone. Darden's fourth quarter diluted net earnings per share from continuing operations were $1.10, both on a reported and adjusted basis. They were 8.9% higher than last year's adjusted diluted net earnings per share. As a reminder, last year was a 14-week fiscal quarter. The 8.9% growth assumes a 13-week quarter last year. 
Additionally, this quarter we paid out over $63 million in dividends and repurchased approximately $45 million in Darden stock. Key drivers of this quarter's growth included: Positive same-restaurant sales of 1.7% on a fiscal basis; continued progress achieving our cost-savings initiatives throughout the P&L; favorable commodities environment resulting in approximately 1% deflation in food and beverage expense; and depreciation and interest expense savings related to the real estate transactions. 
These results were partially offset by 170 basis points of incremental rent and other taxes related to the real estate transaction. Excluding the additional rent expense and other taxes, restaurant expenses would have been favorable by approximately 200 -- 20 basis points. And while our adjusted tax rate was in line with the expectations we shared last quarter, tax expense as a percent of sales was 80 basis points unfavorable to last year driven by tax timing. 
Turning to segment performance. As a reminder, fiscal 2016 segment profit includes the incremental rent and other tax expense associated with the real estate transactions, whereas fiscal 2015 did not include these costs. 
In total, these costs were $30 million for the quarter. The benefits of lower depreciation and interest savings, which were $27 million, are not recognized in segment profit. 
Olive Garden's segment profit margin of 19.3% was 100 basis points lower than last year for the quarter as additional rent drove 230 basis points of margin unfavorability versus last year. 
Excluding the incremental rent, Olive Garden segment profit margin was 130 basis points higher than last year. LongHorn Steakhouse grew segment profit margin by 120 basis points for the quarter to 19%. Excluding the incremental rent, segment profit increased 250 basis points at LongHorn. 
Our fine dining and other business segment profit margins were essentially flat on a year-over-year basis at 20.1% and 18.9%, respectively, with our other business segment impacted by additional rents. We are pleased with the progress each of our segments has made improving profitability. They're leveraging their sales growth and continuing to improve the guest experience while taking advantage of Darden's scale and working closely with our support teams to identify and capture cost savings. 
Finally, as we announced this morning, our board declared a $0.56 per share quarterly dividend, a 12% increase from last quarter's dividend. We were able to spin-off our real estate into a separate, publicly-traded company and still increase our quarterly dividend above our pre-spend quarterly dividend and our spinoff of real estate assets to Four Corners created additional growth for our shareholders as the current combined dividend of the 2 companies is now 23% higher than the Darden dividend before spinoff of Four Corners this past November. 
Fiscal 2016 was a year of significant progress at Darden. We achieved 4.4% total sales growth on a 52-week basis; 3.3% same-restaurant sales growth; and 38% growth in adjusted diluted net earnings per share. 
In addition to meaningful sales and adjusted earnings per share growth, we profitably grew our market share, exceeding the industry benchmark for same-restaurant sales by over 400 basis points, increased adjusted operating margins by over 200 basis points, leverage our scale, further optimizing our supply chain and managing costs, resulting in $95 million in annual cost-savings, which exceeded our initial targets and returned more than $450 million to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases. 
Importantly, we also executed our real estate strategy by completing a tax-free spin-off of select real estate assets and restaurant assets into a new public company, Four Corners Property Trust. This transaction advanced our commitment to deliver value to our shareholders while improving our capital structure and reducing debt. Using proceeds from this transaction and from the sale-leasebacks of our restaurant support center and 64 restaurants, plus cash on hand, we paid down $1 billion in debt during the quarter -- during the year. This reduction in debt significantly improved our leverage, resulting in a return to investment grade credit status from all 3 credit rating agencies. 
Overall, we're excited we're executing a value-creating business model to generate significant and durable cash flow that will fund growth and return capital to shareholders. 
Now looking forward to fiscal 2017. We anticipate total sales growth of 1.7% to 2.7%, which includes same-restaurant sales growth of 1% to 2% and 24 to 28 new units. Capital spending of between $310 million to $350 million, cost-savings of approximately $30 million, total inflation between 1.5% and 2%, and a net -- and annual effective tax rate between 26% and 27% and approximately 128.5 million diluted average shares outstanding for the year, all resulting in earnings per diluted share between $3.80 and $3.90. 
We anticipate first quarter earnings per share to have the highest growth on a percentage basis as we expect commodities deflation in the first quarter of fiscal 2017 while we forecast commodities inflation in subsequent quarters. 
As a reminder, in December, we shared our framework for value creation, including a 7% to 10% earnings after-tax growth and a 10% to 15% of total shareholder returns calculated as EPS growth plus dividend yield. The metrics for our fiscal 2017 outlook are within the long-term targets we shared this past December with the exception of new restaurant growth. We are working diligently to build the pipeline of new restaurants for future growth. 
And with that, I'll turn it over to Gene.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick. As I think about fiscal 2016, I'm extremely proud of the progress we made in pursuit of our mission, which is to be financially successful through great people, consistently delivering outstanding food, drinks and service, an inviting atmosp
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick. As I think about fiscal 2016, I'm extremely proud of the progress we made in pursuit of our mission, which is to be financially successful through great people, consistently delivering outstanding food, drinks and service, an inviting atmosphere, making every guest loyal. Our results reinforce that our strategy is working as our restaurants and team members continue to build guest loyalty by relentlessly focusing on our back-to-basics operating philosophy, which is rooted in culinary division and execution, attentive service, engaging atmospheres and integrated marketing. 
Finally, we continue to leverage our 4 competitive advantages that we see as keys to unlocking sales growth and expanding margins. They are the significant scale of our company, the breadth and depth of our data and consumer insights, our commitment to rigorous, strategic planning and our results-oriented people culture. It's that last competitive advantage, our people, that truly sets our company apart. Together, we've accomplished a great deal over the past 2 years and we've done it by getting a little better each day. It may sound simple, but it's hard to consistently deliver a outstanding guest experiences day in and day out. 
It only happens because of our 150,000 outstanding team members across our company. 
So let me close by thanking each of them. We know we got a lot more work to do but I'm confident our team is up to the challenge. 
Now, we'll take your questions.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We have our first question, it is coming from Brett Levy of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We have our first question, it is coming from Brett Levy of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Obviously, another quarter of a nice job on the labor line. Can you do us a favor, and talk a little bit through what your thoughts are and how you're managing labor? What you can do on scarce -- given all of the scarcity that's out there, how you're look
componenttext: Obviously, another quarter of a nice job on the labor line. Can you do us a favor, and talk a little bit through what your thoughts are and how you're managing labor? What you can do on scarce -- given all of the scarcity that's out there, how you're looking at inflation and also, have you had an opportunity to assess what kind of impact the changes to overtime will have to your labor line and the way you're approaching business?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, Brett. A couple of things. Let me deal -- the first -- the last point first, which is the labor impact. That will have no impact on our organization. Let me talk about labor. Labor is something that we continue to focus on, but we're focusin
componenttext: Good morning, Brett. A couple of things. Let me deal -- the first -- the last point first, which is the labor impact. That will have no impact on our organization. Let me talk about labor. Labor is something that we continue to focus on, but we're focusing on it in a different way. And we're focusing it on a really -- when we think about menu development, how our menus are constructed and how that leads to processes and procedures in the kitchen. And we just -- we continue to focus on simplification on -- in all aspects of what I would call the production process or the manufacturing process of producing our menu items. Our teams are doing a great job of simplifying the processes and thinking about how products that we have are adding to the menu or we have in the menu impact the production process. And so we've taken products off the menu that are complex. We've simplified processes and procedures, which has allowed us to improve the overall productivity in the back of the house. Obviously, the front of the house is an area where it's kind of off-limits. We have our beliefs in what it takes to execute out front and we're focus on back of the house. We've also got a lot of energy around making sure that we have the appropriate labor in the restaurant at the right times. One of the things that we do with our P&L reviews at the end of each quarter is we sit down and we really look at, "what's the productivity of our restaurants before we have guests in there and then after we don't have guest in there." And we've been able to take a lot of hours out by making some adjustments there. So we feel like we're improving the guest experience, we're working on productivity, with -- in the back of the house with the design of our menus and process and procedures. I'll close by saying and may be preempt some other questions in labor is that, labor market is tight. It continues to be tight in a lot of -- in specific markets, which is driving a little bit more inflation. But as I've said many times on this call, I'd prefer to operate in an environment where labor is tight. I think that will lead to demand into the future.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Would you be able to quantify what your wage rate inflation is or what you're seeing in terms of turnover?
componenttext: Would you be able to quantify what your wage rate inflation is or what you're seeing in terms of turnover?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're seeing 2.5% to 3.5% wage inflation, depending on where we are, in which brand, in which continent, in which part of the country. We've not seen a major tick up in any of our turnover. Actually, our turnover remain strong. We believe in our empl
componenttext: Yes. We're seeing 2.5% to 3.5% wage inflation, depending on where we are, in which brand, in which continent, in which part of the country. We've not seen a major tick up in any of our turnover. Actually, our turnover remain strong. We believe in our employment proposition, we're continuing to look at that and we're -- we provide our employees a tremendous opportunity for advancement and so -- the industry is seeing a pretty good tick up in turnover but we're not seeing it in our Darden brands.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016

componenttext: Question about the outlook for 2017. On the comp front, your 1% to 2% guidance is not the same as your 1% to 3% normalized outlook, I guess, at the mid points, a little below. I guess it was a little over to trend was for May and for the fourth quarter. So what's driving just a slight, slight bit more caution there? Is it recuring environment? Or is it the fact that your lacking some pretty outsize comps? If you could just talk about how you've constructed the comp outlook, I'd appreciate it

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: .Yes. Good morning, Brian. I think that -- what's involved in our outlook guidance of 1% to 2% is we're giving guidance for a very long period of time over the next 12 months. And based on all the things we know today and all that we don't know about th
componenttext:
.
Yes. Good morning, Brian. I think that -- what's involved in our outlook guidance of 1% to 2% is we're giving guidance for a very long period of time over the next 12 months. And based on all the things we know today and all that we don't know about the next 12 months, we think 1% to 2% is a prudent guide. That would indicate that it's still significant outperformance over the industry. And so we believe that's the appropriate guidance at this point in time with all the knowledge that we have.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: That makes a lot of sense and it's pretty solid. On the EPS front, what -- why you guys guiding to a little higher share count year-over-year when you're also saying you're going to buy back a couple hundred -- or $100 million to $200 million of stock? Is
componenttext: That makes a lot of sense and it's pretty solid. On the EPS front, what -- why you guys guiding to a little higher share count year-over-year when you're also saying you're going to buy back a couple hundred -- or $100 million to $200 million of stock? Is there that much dilution going on with stock-based compensation or what's going on there?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brian. This is Rick. A couple of things, there's just a lot of assumptions and factors that make up our share count, including dilution, as you mentioned. Option exercises, new equity grants which really aren't that different from last year and share
componenttext: Yes, Brian. This is Rick. A couple of things, there's just a lot of assumptions and factors that make up our share count, including dilution, as you mentioned. Option exercises, new equity grants which really aren't that different from last year and share price. So the assumptions that we make for share price and the timing of our buybacks. So we thought it was most prudent to just give you a share count number that we're using for our EPS, which we haven't done in the past.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Will Slabaugh of Stephens Inc.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Will Slabaugh of Stephens Inc.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually Bill on for Will this morning. Was interested to hear on your consumers across the brand performs. Are you seeing different trends and some of our higher-end dining relative to the lower end and what you think, from your perspective, is driv
componenttext: It's actually Bill on for Will this morning. Was interested to hear on your consumers across the brand performs. Are you seeing different trends and some of our higher-end dining relative to the lower end and what you think, from your perspective, is driving that behavior? Clearly, we've heard many copies allude to a recent shift in consumer behavior but you have you, at Darden, have seen anything discernible or at least worth noting?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think the way I would talk about consumer behavior is the guest continues to look for value and affordability is only 1 component of that value, but it's not really enough to drive sustainable traffic growth. And so, obviously in an Olive Garden, we
componenttext: No. I think the way I would talk about consumer behavior is the guest continues to look for value and affordability is only 1 component of that value, but it's not really enough to drive sustainable traffic growth. And so, obviously in an Olive Garden, we serve a lot of different guests to get the 5,000 guesting a week, and each guest is looking for something different. But whenever we find something that the consumer really believes has got value, that's where the consumer goes and so that's not all with the lowest price point or then thing that's discounted the most. We still see a lot of guests in LongHorn just gravitate towards a great filet because it's a great value. We saw a high preference in Olive Garden with seafood lasagna, which caught us a little bit by surprise, but it was the best value in the offering that we had. And so I believe the guest continues to look for value and the value equation is not always just what's in the numerator. When you think about -- when we think about our brands, all the way from Olive Garden to Capital Grille, obviously, price plays a lot more importance in creating that value in Olive Garden, where in Capital Grille, it's more about how we make you feel that creates the value in that experience. And so we think about it in go along that line in between Olive Garden and Capital Grille. We're looking for that real value differentiator that will drive traffic. And sometimes, it's affordability and price and sometimes, it's more some of the other attributes and we keep pulling on all of the attributes not just one. And we continue to make improvements in quality, we continue to make improvements in service. That's why we focus so much on execution. We believe at the end of the day, we got to execute at that we call the non [ph] square feet. At that table in every one of our restaurants, one table at a time, that really drives the most value to the consumer. Overall, their behavior continues to be the same period is still see them using the full menu. We've got good interesting appetizers they're buying them. We've got good, interesting deserts, they're buying them. So it's compelling for us to keep coming up with great culinary innovation that make people want to buy our products.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's actually very helpful. And then 1 real quick follow-up if I could with regards to the off-premise and To Go sales. A, what do you think has been the biggest contribution from the company's part in driving the growth and the guests kind of a
componenttext: Got it. That's actually very helpful. And then 1 real quick follow-up if I could with regards to the off-premise and To Go sales. A, what do you think has been the biggest contribution from the company's part in driving the growth and the guests kind of assimilate into that platform? And then second, would you, by chance be willing to be break out what you believe the contribution from that, the online sales were to this quarter's comp?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me address the first part of that question. I think we identified, 4 or 5 years ago, that the needs data convenience was going to continue to grow and that's the one thing that consumer was telling us and the insights was that we don't have enoug
componenttext: Yes. Let me address the first part of that question. I think we identified, 4 or 5 years ago, that the needs data convenience was going to continue to grow and that's the one thing that consumer was telling us and the insights was that we don't have enough time to do all the things that we want to do. We want you to make this more convenient for us. And so we built a platform that enabled us to do that. We've been able to market it effectively. We've been able to deliver it in different ways, whether it's through a traditional To Go experience, whether it's through an online ordering expense, whether it's through both. And now, with this delivery and catering that were doing, we're just giving the consumer another access point to act -- to get what they want, which is something that's convenient, that's high-quality and a great value and that's why, I think, take out is working. We've got a brand its meeting the consumer where the consumer wants to be met. And we have on the percentage?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016

componenttext: Yes, about 20% of our business today is online and that continues to grow each quarter.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. My question as far as the GAAP to your peers, you accelerated that and even widen that the recording what appears to be the month of May. I know obviously, your calendar, nap has a different. So maybe it's not a perfect science. But both brand
componenttext: Understood. My question as far as the GAAP to your peers, you accelerated that and even widen that the recording what appears to be the month of May. I know obviously, your calendar, nap has a different. So maybe it's not a perfect science. But both brands seem to have accelerated in the back half of your fiscal quarter. I wondered if you could elaborate on maybe some of the promotional activity is something that you saw competitively that really lifted up in the back half of the quarter? And my follow-up question would be, you did comment that the commodity environment suggest that the EPS in the first half of fiscal '17 would probably drive greater earnings growth. Is that the same for the same-store sales front as far as what we saw in the month of May? Are we carrying faster, greater momentum? I'm looking at the compares, it would suggest that the first half also will be a comp stronger period in the back half?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Matt. Let me deal with the second part of your question. We're not going to comment on sales trends in June and I wouldn't -- I don't think you should make that leap. I think you should look at the same restaurant sales as 1 to 2 is pretty flat throu
componenttext: Yes, Matt. Let me deal with the second part of your question. We're not going to comment on sales trends in June and I wouldn't -- I don't think you should make that leap. I think you should look at the same restaurant sales as 1 to 2 is pretty flat throughout the year. It's based on what we know right now. And as far as May goes, you are correct. We did accelerate against industry in May. I think that we focused a lot on Mother's Day, in and around Mother's Day, which gave us a great boost. As I've said, Olive Garden had a record Mother's Day. LongHorn and every one of our brands had a record Mother's Day and the days around Mother's Day as we really focused and then we think that drove a lot of the activity in the month. We are -- we really like focusing on these days both from a communications standpoint but from also from an operational standpoint. When you look at Mother's Day in both OG and LongHorn, it's just about how many guests you can get through and execute perfectly throughout the day. And so I think we were active, both digitally and other promotional activity and we executed extremely well. We also got a big bump in catering and delivery for Mother's Day in OG, which was a strong bump. So I think it's -- our teams did a great job. We capitalize on the volume when the volume is there.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from David Palmer of RBC Capital.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from David Palmer of RBC Capital.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you were to audit the sales drivers at Olive Garden for '16 through renovation, LTL, the value platforms, To Go, what were the biggest drivers in your opinion for the year, whether you want to put numbers on it or not? And how do you think about contri
componenttext: If you were to audit the sales drivers at Olive Garden for '16 through renovation, LTL, the value platforms, To Go, what were the biggest drivers in your opinion for the year, whether you want to put numbers on it or not? And how do you think about contributors going into '17? Do you have a sense about how much -- how differently the sales drivers will shape up this next fiscal year?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think there's a few, first, I want to start with we're executing better. And I know sometimes want to look for some other things but I want to pivot back to -- I think Dave, George and Karen, the team at Olive Garden, has done just a great job impr
componenttext: Yes. I think there's a few, first, I want to start with we're executing better. And I know sometimes want to look for some other things but I want to pivot back to -- I think Dave, George and Karen, the team at Olive Garden, has done just a great job improving the day-to-day executions. I think that's the #1 sales revenue. And as I said in my comments, we think we still have meaningful improvement to make their. Second, we think To Go has been a great sales driver. This is been a leader in what we've been doing. We think we're exposing more guests to Olive Garden. It's been a direct sales driver. We've done great culinary innovation. We've hit some really big products. Our pot pies were a big year. Our culinary tour was a big hit. Our create your own tour ovale has been a big hit. Ziosk has been a sales driver. So it's been a good lever. We don't think that we fully hit full stride with that. We've still got some room there. And then remodels have been a solid sales driver, outperforming the base by almost 4% in traffic, between 3% and 4% traffic. So I feel like there's multiple levers, but I want to wrap that back around with our maniacal focus on trying to execute better at the restaurant. We, as a team, and me, especially, believe that is the key driver of winning in this business. Is that interaction between a server and the guest. If we don't win there, all the other things are -- I don't want to say they're meaningless, but they're close. We've got to execute at a very high level, and congratulations to all the Olive Garden people who are listening out there, you did a great, great job.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from David Tarantino of Baird.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from David Tarantino of Baird.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a question about the 2017 margin guidance. It looks like you're assuming margin improvement in line with your long run targets. But I think you also should be seeing some carryover benefits and new benefits from some of the cost-savings that you ac
componenttext: I have a question about the 2017 margin guidance. It looks like you're assuming margin improvement in line with your long run targets. But I think you also should be seeing some carryover benefits and new benefits from some of the cost-savings that you achieved. So my question is, is there something offsetting the cost-savings from an investment perspective that's preventing the margin expansion from being above the range you normally would expect going forward?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, David. There's a couple of thing. I would say, one, we have the second half of the real estate that we have to wrap on. A real estate primarily offsets the $30 million of cost saves that we talked about for next year. And if we get cost savings great
componenttext: Yes, David. There's a couple of thing. I would say, one, we have the second half of the real estate that we have to wrap on. A real estate primarily offsets the $30 million of cost saves that we talked about for next year. And if we get cost savings greater that that, we're going to reinvest in our business to drive sales growth. So while we're still in our long-term framework, again, the real estate transaction and the rents, et cetera, are offsetting our cost saves.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. That's helpful. And then one more clarification on the guidance. On the COGS outlook, are you -- what's the -- can you give us a sense of what the breakdown in the comps might look like from a check and traffic standpoint? Or at least what you're a
componenttext: Great. That's helpful. And then one more clarification on the guidance. On the COGS outlook, are you -- what's the -- can you give us a sense of what the breakdown in the comps might look like from a check and traffic standpoint? Or at least what you're assuming at this stage?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. What we're assuming, David is, we're going to be on the low-end of our 1% to 2% pricing in next year and so we do assume some traffic growth in our guidance.
componenttext: Yes. What we're assuming, David is, we're going to be on the low-end of our 1% to 2% pricing in next year and so we do assume some traffic growth in our guidance.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from John Glass of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from John Glass of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to go back to 1% to 2% outlook for next year as well. It is a little lower than your 1% to 3%. One, what is your assumption on the industry? Is this is as an industry generated slower second be more explicit about that? And I think you been a littl
componenttext: I want to go back to 1% to 2% outlook for next year as well. It is a little lower than your 1% to 3%. One, what is your assumption on the industry? Is this is as an industry generated slower second be more explicit about that? And I think you been a little more restraint around pricing? Do you think price value is becoming a bigger issue in the industry that's hwy you're being more restrained on that as well?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, that's a great question. We are -- as Rick said, we're right now on the lower end of the pricing thinking is that we're going to be in the 1% kind of range, depending on the business. But we definitely think Olive Garden can [ph] be more than 1
componenttext: Yes, John, that's a great question. We are -- as Rick said, we're right now on the lower end of the pricing thinking is that we're going to be in the 1% kind of range, depending on the business. But we definitely think Olive Garden can [ph] be more than 1% in the current environment. We're looking at an industry last year that was down 1 3 -- trending -- I'm sorry, that was the quarter. We're Looking at an industry that's down closer to 2% or high ones. We working off that number. And so, we're looking at a meaningful outperformance with minimal price as we continue to try to improve the value, offerings in our businesses. We to continue to invest. There's a lot of talk about how promotional the environment is right now. But the facts are, the industry still charging the guest 2-plus percent more than they did last year for the experience. And we believe that '17, with what we know right now, is a year to invest, continue to invest back into the guest experience, to continue to grow market share. And if we believe if the overall industry was to improve, then I think we think we would improve also. But based on the current trends and what's happening in the last couple of years, we think this is the right way to head into fiscal '17.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up, on LongHorn, do you think the shifted promotional activity serving sales there? I understand you're still outperforming, but the sales are lower and traffic is now negative? Is that shift and promotion partly to blame for that or not?
componenttext: Just a follow-up, on LongHorn, do you think the shifted promotional activity serving sales there? I understand you're still outperforming, but the sales are lower and traffic is now negative? Is that shift and promotion partly to blame for that or not?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's only half the question. I think you have to go to the P&L and look at how much more money that were making. Were doing right now is, we through our data insights. We identified there for certain guests in the LongHorn system that we were lo
componenttext: I think that's only half the question. I think you have to go to the P&L and look at how much more money that were making. Were doing right now is, we through our data insights. We identified there for certain guests in the LongHorn system that we were losing money on. And it was obvious to us and Rick's team did an outstanding job and we backed off trying to attract those guests into the restaurant and saying, "If we can't make money on the guest taking up a table in a Saturday night, we're not going to push to bring them in." So there are few guests that are slipping out that were in our base last year but they were unprofitable. I'm incredibly impressed with the margin improvement and the progress that we're making at LongHorn and the teams done an outstanding job and I'm not as concerned about where we are from a traffic standpoint. This model is starting to get back to work the way the model was designed to work many, many years ago. And I'm super excited about the trajectory of this business, especially when you look at where the sales are and the margins.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is coming from Jason West of Credit Suisse.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016

componenttext: A couple of questions. One, I guess, Gene, you have are probably better visibility than we do in the industry trends and now that were at the end of June, we had been seeing some slight improvement in May for the industry as you talked about moving away from the Easter shift. Have you seen the industry kind of give that back a bit in June? Is that part of the caution that you're referring to?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016

componenttext: Well, I'm not -- I'm really don't want to comment on June. I don't -- you guys have access to different benchmarks. At this point, I want to talk about fourth quarter and fiscal '16 and we're not going to talk about what's happening in the industry in June.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then a separate question. On the savings outlook, I think you said $30 million baked into the guidance. I think the original target for '17 was $30 million to $40 million, and maybe there was some hope that as you're still digging through the bu
componenttext: Okay. And then a separate question. On the savings outlook, I think you said $30 million baked into the guidance. I think the original target for '17 was $30 million to $40 million, and maybe there was some hope that as you're still digging through the business lines that you'll find the some additional savings. So would you say the $30 million is conservative? And you're still sort of looking for other opportunities? Or have you kind of tapped out with what you can do there?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, a couple of things, Jason. One, we got a little bit more of the savings in the fourth quarter of this year. So that was $5 million more than we had originally anticipated. So we're -- that gets you $30 million to $35 million. We just made the decisio
componenttext: Yes, a couple of things, Jason. One, we got a little bit more of the savings in the fourth quarter of this year. So that was $5 million more than we had originally anticipated. So we're -- that gets you $30 million to $35 million. We just made the decision that we can invest some of the savings. So if we find over $30 million, we're going to reinvest in our business. So we're going to continue to look for cost-savings where it makes sense, where it does impact the guest experience and use those cost-savings to continue to improve the value equation at all of our brands, especially in Olive Garden. So 30 is where we think we are. I'm not saying it's conservative, I'm saying that's we're going to be net and if we find more, we'll probably reinvest those.

componenttext: Just a follow-up on share repurchase and free cash flow. A couple of different questions there. So delivered a second year of almost $600 million in free cash in '16. And just curious why you were not more aggressive with putting some of that the work in terms of share repurchase?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. A couple of things, Jeff. One, is we've given you the long-term framework of $100 million to $200 of share repurchase. We've have $500 million of share repurchase of the board has authorized. We have $315 million left in that. We'll continue to find
componenttext: Yes. A couple of things, Jeff. One, is we've given you the long-term framework of $100 million to $200 of share repurchase. We've have $500 million of share repurchase of the board has authorized. We have $315 million left in that. We'll continue to find opportunities and work with our board to understand the best uses of our cash going forward. But the share repurchase we have is within our long-term framework.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just to sort to beat the horse on this one, so FY '17, similar setup, you guys are going to raise your CapEx by about $100 million, but still about $0.5 billion in free cash. So it's still assumes like a similar nice problem to have, just t
componenttext: Okay. And then just to sort to beat the horse on this one, so FY '17, similar setup, you guys are going to raise your CapEx by about $100 million, but still about $0.5 billion in free cash. So it's still assumes like a similar nice problem to have, just throwing off a ton of free cash. So again, because about the repurchase but then also you just alluded to this the best uses. What else is out there? What do you guys re considering other than potentially modestly accelerating unit growth, remodels, returning cash to shareholders through the form of [indiscernible] what else is the board thinking about?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is gene. We're constantly -- in constant communication with our board about what's the best thing for us to do as we move forward. We're looking -- we'll continue to look at all the alternatives available to us with our excess cash, our capital
componenttext: Yes, this is gene. We're constantly -- in constant communication with our board about what's the best thing for us to do as we move forward. We're looking -- we'll continue to look at all the alternatives available to us with our excess cash, our capital structure and we'll continue to make the prudent decisions to invest in the business long term. And we'll evaluate what the opportunities are every quarter. Obviously, we just finished our year-end board meeting and we'll get back together in September and we'll evaluate the opportunities that are available to us at that time. You alluded to this is a good opportunity for us and we'll continue to evaluate and make the right decisions. But at this point in time, we have no further comments.

componenttext: Gene, many restaurants are talking about retooling or development firms are much is because there believe their message is still. With you feel Olive Garden needs altering or it's enhancing its everyday value platform at all?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think with any to focus on in Olive Garden without talking too much to our competitors right now is continuing to expand the offerings between $10 and $15. We've got the $9.99 [ph] platform which really anchors ourselves at dinner. We have the $6.99 at
componenttext: I think with any to focus on in Olive Garden without talking too much to our competitors right now is continuing to expand the offerings between $10 and $15. We've got the $9.99 [ph] platform which really anchors ourselves at dinner. We have the $6.99 at lunch, but we're looking for different ways of deliver value somewhere in that $10 to $15 range to give the consumer just a few more options. And we think we have the innovation to do that and so we'll continue to focus on that. But back to a statement made earlier. I'm just as focused on other components of value than we are just on price. And Dave and the team are really working on other ways to provide value for the guests. So let me give you an example of that. The one thing about an Olive Garden where we see the value perception slowdown is go down is how long the people have to wait to come in to our restaurant. So what can we do while they're on their wait to improve that process. If we're starting to play with and test a few things and if we do it correctly, we actually improve the overall value experience without changing anything else in -- on the menu or pricing. And we've got to continue to focus on the other components of value where we talk about the other components in the numerator and just not focus on what's on the denominator or the value equation. And so we do need to work at certain price points, but we do need to execute some of those other variables.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Just 2 questions. One, following up on the balance sheet discussion before and specifically, around maybe leverage. It does seem like the industry is ramping up often with the help, I guess, from franchising or should I say, really franchises which
componenttext: Great. Just 2 questions. One, following up on the balance sheet discussion before and specifically, around maybe leverage. It does seem like the industry is ramping up often with the help, I guess, from franchising or should I say, really franchises which is conjured at Darden which is been paying down. I think you mentioned $1 billion this year, but post real estate spin and you've got, investment-great. Some just want you maybe can give an outlook on both fronts, both debt and maybe a target that levels and the potential for any we franchising I think in the past imagine maybe along on opportunity. But just wondering how you think about the leverage opportunity relatively conservative level today?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jeff. As we've said before, our first priority is to maintain our investment-great profile and we just -- we're just upgraded by all 3 agencies in the fourth quarter. We think that's great news. Our targeted debt coverage is 2x to 2.5x adjusted debt
componenttext: Sure, Jeff. As we've said before, our first priority is to maintain our investment-great profile and we just -- we're just upgraded by all 3 agencies in the fourth quarter. We think that's great news. Our targeted debt coverage is 2x to 2.5x adjusted debt to adjusted EBITDAR. And right now, we're right a very low end of that range. And we continued -- we could to be in that range. to be within that range and will continue to demonstrate a sound fiscal policy. We're not going to talk much about franchising going forward but just to 2 to 2.5 is where we expect it to be.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. And then just the comment you made at the end of the unit growth I guess you said that's where you're going to fall short potential in fiscal '17. I've seen in the slide you breakout unit growth by brand in terms of expectation. I'm just wonderin
componenttext: Got you. And then just the comment you made at the end of the unit growth I guess you said that's where you're going to fall short potential in fiscal '17. I've seen in the slide you breakout unit growth by brand in terms of expectation. I'm just wondering if he can offer a little color, again, being below your target level. I mean it seems like Olive Garden and LongHorn are the 2 brands that is still carrying it in '17. Whereas, the other brands are all doing quite well. It's very modest growth. So I'm wondering, your outlook for Olive Garden perhaps, in future years whereas, that's the number that goes up or whether it expect some of these elements to start to ramp things up based on the strong performance?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Good question, Jeff. When you turn the development pipeline on -- off, it's pretty difficult to turn it back on and so we're in the process of turning the development pipeline back on the it's easier and your results come quicker and your Casual Dini
componenttext: Yes. Good question, Jeff. When you turn the development pipeline on -- off, it's pretty difficult to turn it back on and so we're in the process of turning the development pipeline back on the it's easier and your results come quicker and your Casual Dining brands, your Olive Garden's, your LongHorn's. Our specialty brands, it's a longer lead time from a development standpoint. And so we would look for the smaller brands to actually pick up and makeup that differential in the GAAP. We need Yard House to grow at 8% to 10%. We need Seasons to grow at 5% to 8% into the future. We're very pleased with what's going on with breeze. We need them to -- we're making some commitments there. I would just say, this is just a function of the lead time of the specialty brands and the kind of property that we need. We're working diligently. We've got the whole development function working on getting us in, making sure that we're in a range in fiscal '18.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016

componenttext: Understood. And just to clarify the comment earlier about May comps, seeing an improvement, I think you said a big focus on Mother's Day and otherwise. componenttext: Yes. Memorial Day, for the fiscal and the calendar really kind of offset each other. So Memorial Day wasn't really that big of an impact for us.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: So another question on the labor line. If you look at -- it seems like your labor away or wage inflation outlook has tick up up a little bit from how you're talking about taking then price down a little bit, cost cuts are swelling. With expectation be tha
componenttext: So another question on the labor line. If you look at -- it seems like your labor away or wage inflation outlook has tick up up a little bit from how you're talking about taking then price down a little bit, cost cuts are swelling. With expectation be that you can see leverage the labor line and an overall basis? Or is it something where we might actually see a little bit of deleverage this year?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Karen. I think that were probably not going to see a lot of leverage there unless we get outside our sales range. I think that we'll continue to search for productivity enhancements in the back of the house through our processes and procedures and we
componenttext: Yes, Karen. I think that were probably not going to see a lot of leverage there unless we get outside our sales range. I think that we'll continue to search for productivity enhancements in the back of the house through our processes and procedures and we'll continue to manage wage rates effectively. We're also going to continue to evaluate, how do we improve our overall employment proposition so that we have other ways to attract employees not just through paying them more in a salary. So overall, I think we're looking at this right now to try to hold labor flat throughout the year.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Andy Barish of Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Andy Barish of Jefferies.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick ones on any daypart commentary or differences, particularly in the Olive Garden business and then also in Olive Garden. Where you stand for fiscal '17 remodels, both as you look at the bars as well as the full remodels?
componenttext: Just 2 quick ones on any daypart commentary or differences, particularly in the Olive Garden business and then also in Olive Garden. Where you stand for fiscal '17 remodels, both as you look at the bars as well as the full remodels?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're seeing no difference in dayparts, Andy. There's in -- in Olive Garden there's a little bit of a fluctuation depending on what we're doing and what we did the year before. But overall, we look at -- when you look at it on a trailing trend, there's no
componenttext: We're seeing no difference in dayparts, Andy. There's in -- in Olive Garden there's a little bit of a fluctuation depending on what we're doing and what we did the year before. But overall, we look at -- when you look at it on a trailing trend, there's not a lot of noise there. As far as remodels, we're going to do 62 full remodels in '17 and we've got 155 planned bar refreshes and just remind everybody, that's when we go in and we take these bars that don't have very comfortable seating and we put in very comfortable seating. We add TVs and basically, we turn these bar areas that aren't very productive today into productive dining seats and we're seeing a very small lift. It's a $20,000 to $25,000 investment and it's more than paying for itself. And just go in and the full year run in the bars and that this means the bars that we don't have to touch it.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Sara Senatore of Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Sara Senatore of Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of follow-up question. The first on LongHorn, I think you had been saying now for a couple of quarters that it's a very deliberate decision to try to look at the -- who's profitable for the customer this. But that, thing import you had thoug
componenttext: Just a couple of follow-up question. The first on LongHorn, I think you had been saying now for a couple of quarters that it's a very deliberate decision to try to look at the -- who's profitable for the customer this. But that, thing import you had thought that as you may be -- as some of those less profitable customers leave, it makes room for more profitable customers, the higher-margin customers who are not turned away by the lines or to the capacity restaurants. But I guess given the traffic is negative, is it going to take a while for that to happen? Because it seems like they less profitable customers are leaving but you're not getting -- are not bringing in some of these more profitable customers that I've thought you had in mind would sort of fill the GAAP. So I guess I'm just trying to understand the dynamic over the the next couple of quarters, when that might have been. So that's a long, long question and then I do have another follow-up on Olive Garden, please.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. When we think about LongHorn. First -- let's start -- we're still, from a guess comp basis, still 200 basis points above the industry. So we're still taking market share from a guest comp standpoint. And I think that's in itself very impressive when
componenttext: Okay. When we think about LongHorn. First -- let's start -- we're still, from a guess comp basis, still 200 basis points above the industry. So we're still taking market share from a guest comp standpoint. And I think that's in itself very impressive when you look at the rest of the competitive set. We're continuing to make improvements that are going to take quality improvements, that are going to take time to show through to the guest. We've done some things when the price of beef was increasing, that I think hurt the business. But both by changing and we're going back to them tomorrow. It doesn't mean a guess is going to come the next day, it's my to take time for our guests to come to an expense -- and have a different expense and grow the business. And so when I'll look at this business -- and this is the 1 that I'm personally most familiar with, this is a business that has been underperforming from a profitability standpoint and has been on a little differently over the years and then I think it should've been run and now we're running it back. This has never been a great -- a business that needed a lot of high -- a high guest count to achieve its profitability. These are small boxes that are designed to put out a strong, profitable return and then when that business -- building gets full, you build another building 4 miles down the road. And you look at the -- and you look at how this business set up in Atlanta where we have 45 restaurants. There's no one -- in dining, casual dining that comes close to having the kind of penetration we have with a strategy that we put in place in there. And so we are back to building smaller restaurants and focused on ensuring that we're getting the right profitability from those units. We are going to make strategic choices to improve the overall quality of the expense. It's going to take time for those things to get into the consumer for the consumer to see those and then start and improving their frequency. We're reaching other guests that we weren't reaching because of our advertising and how we're talking about the brand. And so I'm really confident, directionally with where we're going and this business is contributing now at a much more -- at a level that's, I think appropriate where it has under contributed, even though it was growing sales all these quarters, it wasn't making any money.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just on Olive Garden. You had mentioned meaningful operations improvements you can still capture. Can you talk about what that looks like? And is that more about top line or efficiency around the cost line created just as I think about all that y
componenttext: And then just on Olive Garden. You had mentioned meaningful operations improvements you can still capture. Can you talk about what that looks like? And is that more about top line or efficiency around the cost line created just as I think about all that you've done so far, there's been a lot of -- a tremendous amount of change, it feels like it also I'm just trying to in this and maybe what's left in terms of the driver of the business going forward?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: When I think about meaningful, I think about it in a few -- on a few different dimensions but, first, I think that we still breakdown too many times in Olive Garden where somewhere in the service experience we have the deficiency. Whether it's the timing
componenttext: When I think about meaningful, I think about it in a few -- on a few different dimensions but, first, I think that we still breakdown too many times in Olive Garden where somewhere in the service experience we have the deficiency. Whether it's the timing wasn't right, the server didn't get the table at the right time, the food didn't come out right. When you're talking about the number of guests that we serve, improving that by 1% or 2% has a significant impact on improving our same-restaurant sales. And so when we think about just consistently delivering a better experience, I think that's a #1 opportunity for us. We still got room to improve on production and menu simplification. Some of the recipes they -- are still complex and Dave and the team are thinking about it every day. How do I make that less complex to be able to deliver that to the consumer? There's labor productivity opportunities. We still -- in a system the size of Olive Garden, we can see in our own data, we have opportunities for certain restaurants to improve productivity. Sometimes, and what the team has done a really good job was, they just haven't gone to the lower volume restaurants. Some of the time, the opportunity that -- was opportunity we have is in the higher volume restaurants and so they're developing ways to analyze and really discern, "Where are my real opportunities to improve productivity?" There's some controllable cost and management of controllable costs that still, we have people that don't perform at the same level of other. So this execution will opportunity there. And then lastly, we still think we can execute To Go better. And we think that that's a huge opportunity for us, as well as we're doing, we believe there's an opportunity to improve that even further.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Andrew Strelzik BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Andrew Strelzik BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a bigger picture question on To Go and delivery. We're hearing a lot of -- a number of concepts across industry talk about focusing on delivery and To Go and putting up very nice growth rates, like yourselves. So I'm wondering the next couple of year
componenttext: Just a bigger picture question on To Go and delivery. We're hearing a lot of -- a number of concepts across industry talk about focusing on delivery and To Go and putting up very nice growth rates, like yourselves. So I'm wondering the next couple of years, higher thinking that this plays out? I mean is this a kind of a rising tide with saw both sides of the question where we're giving guests with something that they be looking for? And so broadly, this was going to work was there something specific to Darden? And where do you think those eating locations are coming from? Is that all coming from eating out? Or how do you think this plays out over time?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Good question. I do think there's opportunity for everybody in the to capture new business. Where we believe Olive Garden is better situated is the kind of food that we serve. If you're bar and grill, it's not like you can put 20 hamburgers in a cont
componenttext: Yes. Good question. I do think there's opportunity for everybody in the to capture new business. Where we believe Olive Garden is better situated is the kind of food that we serve. If you're bar and grill, it's not like you can put 20 hamburgers in a container and send the [ph] home and have them put everything together and still have a quality product. But we can stay at home pan the lasagna, pan the chicken parmesan. I think it's the style of food that we serve really lends itself this trend is taking place. And so I think we're -- Olive Garden, we're better situated. We're seeing To Go sales increase in LongHorn. But we don't believe -- we need to go with what the consumer wants to. But we don't believe we have a platform to really -- in LongHorn, with the style of food, to be able to push that to a 20% of our overall business. What we think that it's something Olive Garden has a real capability. Third-party delivery is something that's going to need to evolve, it's going to effect the overall industry and there are a lot of big names out there trying to figure out how they're going to solve -- how they're going to come up with a solution to solve this problem. And I would say, that's a stay tuned. Because there's just a lot of activity there the big one, but there's a lot of dollars for our company, and I won't mention any names, if they can come up with a solution to -- for us and for our Casual Dining and all of dining, there's some money to be made there.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is coming from Joshua Long of Piper Jaffray.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question was on the technology update and just really, the technology opportunity. You mentioned that Ziosk has already been a sales driver for you. So I was just curious, just and kind of a capacity or what inning you think you are in terms of being a
componenttext: My question was on the technology update and just really, the technology opportunity. You mentioned that Ziosk has already been a sales driver for you. So I was just curious, just and kind of a capacity or what inning you think you are in terms of being able to turn on these features? You haven't rolled that to restaurants, so I'm sure you still going through in learning how to use it and not only from a guest perspective but maybe there might be an opportunity for it to help with labor management or things in the back of the House the biggest lesson to see. So just curious on where you are with an update and kind of what the opportunities might be to layer on additional features going forward in '17 and beyond?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we haven't wrapped yet on our implementation of Ziosk. So we still have a little bit To Go and a lot more trying to do to teach the service and the teams how to use of that most effectively to improve the service expense for the guests. As we've
componenttext: Sure. So we haven't wrapped yet on our implementation of Ziosk. So we still have a little bit To Go and a lot more trying to do to teach the service and the teams how to use of that most effectively to improve the service expense for the guests. As we've said, the benefit of that device isn't -- we're not expecting to take labor out of the systems because of the device. We expect to continue to increase sales. We get a lot of data from our guests, many more of them are filling up the surveys so we learn a lot more. And it actually improves the biggest pain point that a guest has, is paying at the table. So we believe that we're still early stages of getting all of the benefits from the Ziosk device that we can get as we build on other things of that device. Again, nothing in the back of the house that would be saved from that. We're thinking about looking at loyalty and how to use loyalty with Ziosk. But were still in a very early stages of that as well. But we're learning some things we can use for training and other things. So still a long way to go there but we feel really good about where we are.

componenttext: Well, can say that we launched To Go online 2 years ago in July and we saw 20% increases in the first year in 20% increases in the second year. I can't of that we'll see 20% increases in the third year. However, we can continue to improve our to experience and convenience is a big driver of our to go experience. We'll say on the catering said, the deliveries that were doing, we're getting almost 100% of the people saying that they're going to reorder a mother going to do this again. So as that becomes bigger and bigger, it will become a bigger and bigger part of our by. So we would continue to expect delivery and catering to go to grow for us. And we think we've said in the past that we expect To Go to be, in the long run, 20% of our business.
