componenttext: Beef? Is beef part of the contract? Yes, we've got -- we're pretty open in the back half of the year on beef. So we've got, as I said, 60% of our total commodities covered in the first half, but 45% of that is beef.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Jeff Bernstein of Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Jeff Bernstein of Barclays.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Just 2 questions: One, following up on the balance sheet discussion before and specifically, around maybe leverage. It does seem like the industry is ramping up often with the help, I guess, from franchising or should I say, refranchising, which is
componenttext: Great. Just 2 questions: One, following up on the balance sheet discussion before and specifically, around maybe leverage. It does seem like the industry is ramping up often with the help, I guess, from franchising or should I say, refranchising, which is contrary to Darden, which has been paying down, I think you mentioned, $1 billion this year. But post the real estate spin and you've got the upgrade to the investment grade. So I'm just wondering, maybe you can give an outlook on both fronts, both debt, maybe your target debt levels and the potential for any refranchising. I think in the past, you'd mention maybe LongHorn opportunity. But just wondering how you think about that leverage opportunity relative to the conservative level today.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jeff. As we've said before, our first priority is to maintain our investment-grade profile and we just -- we're upgraded by all 3 agencies in the fourth quarter. We think that's great news. Our targeted debt coverage is 2x to 2.5x adjusted debt to a
componenttext: Sure, Jeff. As we've said before, our first priority is to maintain our investment-grade profile and we just -- we're upgraded by all 3 agencies in the fourth quarter. We think that's great news. Our targeted debt coverage is 2x to 2.5x adjusted debt to adjusted EBITDAR. And right now, we're at the very low end of that range. And we continue to say we're going to be within that range. And we'll continue to demonstrate sound fiscal policy. We're not going to talk much about franchising going forward but just the 2 to 2.5 is where we expect to be.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. And then just the comment you guys made on the, I think on the unit growth. I guess that, that was where you're going to fall short potentially in fiscal '17. I see in the slides you breakout unit growth by brand in terms of expectation. So I'm j
componenttext: Got you. And then just the comment you guys made on the, I think on the unit growth. I guess that, that was where you're going to fall short potentially in fiscal '17. I see in the slides you breakout unit growth by brand in terms of expectation. So I'm just wondering if you can offer a little color, again, being below your target level. I mean, it seems like Olive Garden and LongHorn are the 2 brands that are still carrying it in '17. Whereas, the other brands that are all doing quite well, there's very modest growth. So I'm wondering, your outlook for Olive Garden perhaps, in future years, whether that's a number that goes up or whether you would expect some of the other brands to start to ramp things up based on their strong performance.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Good question, Jeff. When you turn the development pipeline on -- off, it's pretty difficult to turn it back on. And so we're in the process of turning the development pipeline back on. It's easier and your results come quicker in your casual dining
componenttext: Yes. Good question, Jeff. When you turn the development pipeline on -- off, it's pretty difficult to turn it back on. And so we're in the process of turning the development pipeline back on. It's easier and your results come quicker in your casual dining brands, your Olive Garden, your LongHorns. Our specialty brands, it's a longer lead time from a development standpoint. And so we would look for the smaller brands to actually pick up and make up that differential in the gap. We need Yard House to grow at 8% to 10%. We need Seasons to grow at 5% to 8% into the future. We're very pleased with what's going on with Breeze. We need them to -- we're making some commitments there. I would just say, this is just the function of the lead time of the specialty brands and the kind of property that we need. We're working diligently. We've got the whole development function working on getting us in, making sure that we're in range in fiscal '18.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And just to clarify the comment earlier about May comps, seeing an improvement. I think you said a big focus on Mother's Day and otherwise. Was there any shift from a Memorial Day perspective? I know, you had said earlier in the call that mayb
componenttext: Understood. And just to clarify the comment earlier about May comps, seeing an improvement. I think you said a big focus on Mother's Day and otherwise. Was there any shift from a Memorial Day perspective? I know, you had said earlier in the call that maybe there was some few different shifts, and in the end, that hurt you guys. So I was wondering Memorial Day specifically in May might have helped.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Memorial Day, for the fiscal and the calendar really kind of offset each other. So Memorial Day wasn't really that big of an impact for us.
componenttext: Yes. Memorial Day, for the fiscal and the calendar really kind of offset each other. So Memorial Day wasn't really that big of an impact for us.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Karen Holthouse of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Karen Holthouse of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: So another question on the labor line. If you look at -- it seems like your labor -- or your wage inflation outlook has ticked up a little bit from how you were talking about that, taking then price down a little bit. Cost cuts are slowing. Would the expe
componenttext: So another question on the labor line. If you look at -- it seems like your labor -- or your wage inflation outlook has ticked up a little bit from how you were talking about that, taking then price down a little bit. Cost cuts are slowing. Would the expectation be that you can still leverage the labor line on an overall basis? Or is it something where we might actually see a little bit of deleverage this year?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Karen. I think that we're going to -- probably not going to see a whole lot of leverage there unless we get outside our sales range. I think that we'll continue to search for our productivity enhancements in the back of the house through our processe
componenttext: Yes, Karen. I think that we're going to -- probably not going to see a whole lot of leverage there unless we get outside our sales range. I think that we'll continue to search for our productivity enhancements in the back of the house through our processes and procedures. And we'll continue to manage wage rates effectively. We're also going to continue to evaluate, how do we improve our overall employment proposition so that we have other ways to attract employees, not just through paying them more in a salary. So overall, I think we're looking at this right now to try to hold labor flat throughout the year.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Andy Barish of Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Andy Barish of Jefferies.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick ones on any daypart commentary or differences, particularly in the Olive Garden business. And then also on Olive Garden, where you stand for fiscal '17 remodels, both as you look at the bars as well as the full remodels?
componenttext: Just 2 quick ones on any daypart commentary or differences, particularly in the Olive Garden business. And then also on Olive Garden, where you stand for fiscal '17 remodels, both as you look at the bars as well as the full remodels?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're seeing no difference in dayparts, Andy. There's a -- in Olive Garden, there's a little bit of fluctuation depending on what we're doing and what we did the year before. But overall, we look at -- when you really look at it on a trailing trend,
componenttext: Yes, we're seeing no difference in dayparts, Andy. There's a -- in Olive Garden, there's a little bit of fluctuation depending on what we're doing and what we did the year before. But overall, we look at -- when you really look at it on a trailing trend, there's not a lot of noise there. As far as remodels, we're going to do 62 full remodels in '17, and we've got 155 planned bar refreshes. And just remind everybody, that's when we go in and we take these bars that don't have very comfortable seating and we put in very comfortable seating. We add TVs. And basically, we turn these bar areas that aren't very productive today into productive dining seats and we're seeing a very small lift. It's a $20,000 to $25,000 investment and it's more than paying for itself. And it's just -- when we go in and do the full remodel and the bar is done, that just means the bar is done and we don't have to touch it.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Sara Senatore of Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Sara Senatore of Bernstein.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of follow-up questions, the first on LongHorn. I think you had been saying now for a couple of quarters that it's a very deliberate decision to try to look at the -- who's profitable in your customer base. But that I think in part, you had t
componenttext: Just a couple of follow-up questions, the first on LongHorn. I think you had been saying now for a couple of quarters that it's a very deliberate decision to try to look at the -- who's profitable in your customer base. But that I think in part, you had thought that as you may be -- as some of those less-profitable customers leave, it makes room for more profitable customers, the higher-margin customers who are not turned away by the lines or the -- at-capacity restaurants. But I guess given the traffic is negative, is it going to take a while for that to happen? Because it seems like the less-profitable customers are leaving but you're not getting -- you're not bringing in some of these more-profitable customers that I thought you had in mind would sort of fill the gap. So I guess, I'm just trying to understand the dynamic over the next couple of quarters, when that might happen. So that's a long, long question. And then, I do have another follow-up on Olive Garden, please.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. When we think about LongHorn, first -- let's start -- we're still, from a guest count basis, still 200 basis points above the industry. So we're still taking market share from a guest count standpoint. And I think that's, in itself, very impressive
componenttext: Okay. When we think about LongHorn, first -- let's start -- we're still, from a guest count basis, still 200 basis points above the industry. So we're still taking market share from a guest count standpoint. And I think that's, in itself, very impressive when you look at the rest of the competitive set. We're continuing to make improvements that are going to take quality improvements, that are going to take time to show through to the guest. We've done some things when the price of beef was increasing, that I think hurt the business. But just by changing and we're going back to them tomorrow, doesn't mean a guest is going to come the next day. It's going to take time for our guests to come through and experience -- have a different experience and grow the business. And so when I look at this business -- and this is the one that I'm personally the most familiar with. This is a business that has been underperforming from a profitability standpoint and has been run a little differently over the years than, I think, it should've been run, and now we're running it back. This has never been a great -- a business that needed a lot of -- high guest counts to achieve its profitability. These are small boxes that are designed to put out a strong, profitable return, and then when that business -- building gets full, you build another building 4 miles down the road. And you look at the -- you look at how this business is really set up in Atlanta, where we have 45 restaurants, there's no one -- in dining, casual dining -- that comes close to having the kind of penetration we have with the strategy that we put in place there. And so we are back to building smaller restaurants and focused on ensuring that we're getting the right profitability from those units. We are going to make strategic choices to improve the overall quality of the experience. It's going to take time for those things to get into the consumer, for the consumer to see those and then start improving their frequency. We're reaching other guests that we weren't reaching because of our advertising and how we're talking about the brand. And so I'm really confident, directionally with where we're going and this business is contributing now at a much more -- at a level that's, I think, appropriate, where it has under contributed. Even though it was growing sales all these quarters, it wasn't making any money.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just on Olive Garden, you had mentioned meaningful operations improvements you can still capture. Can you talk about what that looks like? And is that more about top line or efficiency around the cost line? Just as I think about all that you've d
componenttext: And then just on Olive Garden, you had mentioned meaningful operations improvements you can still capture. Can you talk about what that looks like? And is that more about top line or efficiency around the cost line? Just as I think about all that you've done so far, there's been a lot of -- a tremendous amount of change it feels like at Olive Garden. So I'm just trying to understand maybe what's left in terms of a driver of the business going forward.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, when I think about meeting -- if I think about it in a few -- on a few different dimensions. But first, I think that we still break down too many times in Olive Garden, where the -- where somewhere in the service experience, we have a deficiency, whe
componenttext: Yes, when I think about meeting -- if I think about it in a few -- on a few different dimensions. But first, I think that we still break down too many times in Olive Garden, where the -- where somewhere in the service experience, we have a deficiency, whether it's the timing wasn't right, the server didn't get to the table at the right time, the food didn't come out right. When you're talking about the number of guests that we serve, improving that by 1% or 2% has a significant impact on improving our same-restaurant sales. And so we think about just consistently delivering a better experience, I think that's the #1 opportunity for us. We still got room to improve on production and menu simplification. Some of the recipes they -- are still complex, and Dave and the team are thinking about it every day. How do I make that less complex to be able to deliver that to the consumer? There's labor productivity opportunities. We still -- in a system the size of Olive Garden, we can see in our own data, we have opportunities for certain restaurants to improve productivity. Sometimes -- and what the team has done a really great job was, they just haven't gone to the lower-volume restaurants. Some of the time, the opportunity that -- the most opportunity we have is in our higher-volume restaurants. And so they're developing ways to analyze and really discern, where are my real opportunities to improve productivity? There's some controllable costs and management of controllable costs that still -- we have people that don't perform at the same level of others, so there's executional opportunity there. And then lastly, we still think we can execute To Go better. And we think it's that -- that's a huge opportunity for us. As well as we're doing, we believe there's an opportunity to improve that even further.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Andrew Strelzik of BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Andrew Strelzik of BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just had a bigger picture question on To Go and delivery. We're hearing a lot of -- a number of concepts across industry talk about focusing on delivery and To Go and putting up very nice growth rates, like yourselves. So I'm wondering over the next coupl
componenttext: Just had a bigger picture question on To Go and delivery. We're hearing a lot of -- a number of concepts across industry talk about focusing on delivery and To Go and putting up very nice growth rates, like yourselves. So I'm wondering over the next couple of years, how you're thinking that this plays out. I mean, is this a kind of a rising-tide, lifts-all-boats type of equation, where we're giving guests something that they've been looking for? And so broadly, this was going to work. Or is there something specific to Darden? And where do you think those eating occasions are coming from? Is it all coming from eating at home? Or how do you think this plays out over time?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Good question. I do think there's an opportunity for everybody in the industry to capture this. Where we believe that Olive Garden is better situated is the kind of food that we serve. And so if you're a bar and grill, it's not like you can put 20 ha
componenttext: Yes. Good question. I do think there's an opportunity for everybody in the industry to capture this. Where we believe that Olive Garden is better situated is the kind of food that we serve. And so if you're a bar and grill, it's not like you can put 20 hamburgers in a container and send the rolls home and have them put everything together and still have a quality product. But we can send home pans of lasagna, pans of chicken parmesan. I think that style of food that we serve really lends itself to this trend that's taking place. And so I think we're -- Olive Garden, we're better situated. We're seeing To Go sales increase in LongHorn. But we don't believe -- we need to go with what the consumer wants here. But we don't believe we have a platform to really -- in LongHorn, with the style of food, to be able to push that to 20% of our overall business, where we think that it's something Olive Garden has a real capability. Third-party delivery is something that's going to need to evolve. It's going to affect the overall industry, and there are a lot of big names out there trying to figure out how they're going to -- how they're going to come up with a solution to solve this problem. And I would say, that's a stay-tuned. Because there's just a lot of activity there with the big one. But there's a lot of dollars for our company, and I won't mention any names, if they can come up with a solution to -- for us and for our casual dining and all of dining, there's some money to be made there.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Steve Anderson of Maxim Group.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Steve Anderson of Maxim Group.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016

componenttext: For interest expense for the year? So we've got another reduction -- well, we're interested in about $45 million, I think, for the year, which means it's $26 million less next year than it was this year.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Joshua Long of Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Joshua Long of Piper Jaffray.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question was on the technology update and just really, the technology opportunity. You mentioned that Ziosk has already been a sales driver for you. So I was curious just in kind of what capacity or what inning you think you are in terms of being able
componenttext: My question was on the technology update and just really, the technology opportunity. You mentioned that Ziosk has already been a sales driver for you. So I was curious just in kind of what capacity or what inning you think you are in terms of being able to turn on those features? You haven't rolled that to the restaurants, so I'm sure you're still going through and learning how to use it. And not only from a guest perspective, but maybe there might be an opportunity for it to help with labor management or things in the back of the house where the guest doesn't see. So just curious on where you are with that update. And kind of what the opportunities might be to layer on additional features going forward in '17 and beyond?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we haven't wrapped yet on our implementation of Ziosk. So we still have a little bit to go and a lot more training to do to teach the servers and the teams how to use that the most effectively to improve the service experience for the guests. As
componenttext: Sure. So we haven't wrapped yet on our implementation of Ziosk. So we still have a little bit to go and a lot more training to do to teach the servers and the teams how to use that the most effectively to improve the service experience for the guests. As we've said, the benefit of that device isn't -- we're not expecting to take labor out of the systems because of the device. We expect to continue to increase sales. We get a lot of data from our guests, many more of them are filling out the surveys, so we learn a lot more. And it actually improves the biggest pain point that a guest has, is paying at the table. So we believe that we're still early stages of getting all of the benefits from the Ziosk device that we can get as we build on other things from that device. Again, nothing in the back of the house that would be saved from that. We're thinking about looking at loyalty and how do we use loyalty with Ziosk. But we're still in the very early stages of that as well. But we're learning some things that we can use, to use that for training and other things. So still a long way to go there, but we feel really good about where we are.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016

componenttext: That's helpful. How much of the system has Ziosk or maybe at Olive Garden has Ziosk right now? And if -- kind of what's the expected rollout for '17?

componenttext: At Olive Garden, 100% of the system has Ziosk. We're looking at it to see if it makes sense in other brands. But right now, Olive Garden is the brand that we're focusing most on for the Ziosk.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I can say that we launched To Go online 2 years ago in July and we saw 20% increases in the first year and 20% increases in the second year. I can't tell you that we'll see 20% increases into the third year. However, we continue to improve our To Go
componenttext: Well, I can say that we launched To Go online 2 years ago in July and we saw 20% increases in the first year and 20% increases in the second year. I can't tell you that we'll see 20% increases into the third year. However, we continue to improve our To Go experience, and convenience is a big driver of our To Go experience. We'll say on the catering said, the deliveries that we're doing, we're getting almost 100% of the people saying that they're going to reorder. They're going to do this again. So as that becomes bigger and bigger, it'll become a bigger and bigger part of our pie. So we would continue to expect delivery and catering and To Go to grow for us. And I think we've said in the past that we expect To Go to be, in the long run, 20% of our business.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016

componenttext:
Welcome to the Darden fiscal year 2017 First Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] This conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, please disconnect at this time. 
I will now turn the call over to Mr. Kevin Kalicak. Thank you, and you may begin.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jay. Good morning, and welcome, everyone. With me today is Gene Lee, Darden's CEO; and Rick Cardenas, CFO.As a reminder, comments made during this call will include forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Re
componenttext:
Thank you, Jay. Good morning, and welcome, everyone. With me today is Gene Lee, Darden's CEO; and Rick Cardenas, CFO.
As a reminder, comments made during this call will include forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations and projections.
Those risks are described in the company's press release, which was distributed earlier today, and in its filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
We are simultaneously broadcasting a presentation during this call, which is posted in the Investor Relations section of our website at www.darden.com. Today's discussion and presentation includes certain non-GAAP measurements, and reconciliation of these measurements is included in the presentation.
We plan to release fiscal 2017 second quarter earnings on December 20, before the market opens, followed by a conference call. 
This morning, Gene will share some brief remarks about our quarterly performance and business highlights. Rick will then provide more detail on our financial results from the first quarter and update our outlook for fiscal 2017. And then Gene will have some closing remarks before we open the call for your questions. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Gene.
[Technical Difficulties ‚Äì Please refer to the preliminary transcript that will be posted shortly.]

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Keep going. Cultivate our results [ph] people culture to enable growth. We remain confident that we have the right strategies in place, both in the operating businesses and at the Darden level, and we continue to significantly increase market share as we
componenttext:
Keep going. Cultivate our results [ph] people culture to enable growth. We remain confident that we have the right strategies in place, both in the operating businesses and at the Darden level, and we continue to significantly increase market share as we execute against them. 
All of Darden's positive momentum continued during the quarter. Same-restaurant sales grew 2%, outperforming the industry benchmarks, excluding Darden, by 410 basis points. This was our eighth consecutive quarter of same-restaurant sales growth at Olive Garden. 
The primary drivers of this performance include: 1, our ongoing focus on flawless execution inside the restaurants. Our teams are working hard to get better everyday, which is reflected by the fact that our overall guest satisfaction scores rose to an all-time high during the quarter. 
Two, the strong performance of OG To Go. To Go sales grew 20% compared to the same period last year and more than 50% on a 3-year basis. And 3, culinary innovation. During the quarter, we introduced dishes that build on brand equities and flavor profiles that our loyal guests enjoy most, including pepperoni fettuccine and Italian [ph]. 
Additionally, we continued to interact with our guest in a variety of ways. During the summer, we surprised and delighted many guests by setting up our never ending family table in multiple states across the country. It debuted the high line in New York City where we serve 6,000 guests in 4 hours. This type of nontraditional marketing is popular with millennials and leverages Olive Garden's strong emotional connection. 
The Olive Garden business is strong, and we remain laser-focused on delivering exceptional experience for our guests. 
LongHorn Steakhouse maintained its top line momentum and delivered significant profit growth during the quarter. Same-restaurant sales grew 0.6%, the 14th consecutive quarter of growth, outperforming the industry benchmarks, excluding Darden, by 270 basis points. 
We continue to focus on strengthening our in-restaurant execution to improve the guest experience. One way we're doing this is through operation simplification, which enables our team members the better focus on delivering a quality experience for our guests. 
Another way we're strengthening in-restaurant execution is through enhanced training for our culinary team members because we know perfectly grilled steaks are critical to a great steakhouse experience. This came to light during quarter through our steak masters challenge, a highly engaging training program and 2-month competition that began with 6,000 culinary team members and ended with a grill master, Alex Alvarado, being crowned the stake master champion. 
The team at LongHorn is focused on the right priorities and our research shows that we're making meaningful progress on multiple fronts. 
Turning to our specialty restaurants. All 5 of our businesses continue to perform well and increase share, and each one is well positioned for growth as we build out our pipeline. The Bahama Breeze team delivered another strong quarter. Same-restaurant sales were up 3.9% as guests continue to respond positively to the enhancements we are making to create an immersive experience that feels like a tropical getaway. 
Seasons 52 performed well as same-restaurant sales up 0.7%. We continue to be a leader in culinary innovation and the restaurant of choice for guest, who are conscientious of what they eat but are not willing to compromise taste. Same-restaurant sales were flat at Yard House. I really like what the team is working on as [ph] gets further immersed in the business. 
And finally, the capital [ph] at same-restaurant sales down 1.2 and 1.7, respectively, wrapping on 7.2 and 5.1 same-restaurant sales growth last year. Not only do we anticipate this was going to be a difficult for both brands, Texas continues to be a tough market for our Fine Dining brands. However, if you normalize for Memorial Day, which was observed in Q1 of this year [ph] Q4 of fiscal 2015, the Capital Grille would have been positive. 
Now I'll turn it over to Rick to discuss our results in more detail.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gene, and good morning, everyone. Darden's first quarter diluted net earnings per share from continuing operations were $0.88, an increase of 29.4% from last year's adjusted earnings per share. We returned more than $0.25 billion of capital t
componenttext:
Thank you, Gene, and good morning, everyone. Darden's first quarter diluted net earnings per share from continuing operations were $0.88, an increase of 29.4% from last year's adjusted earnings per share. 
We returned more than $0.25 billion of capital to our shareholders in the form of more than $70 million in dividends and approximately $196 million in share repurchases. And as we announced this morning, our Board of Directors approved a new share repurchase program for up to $500 million of Darden's outstanding common stock. This plan does not have an experience in the and it replaced the previous plan. 
For clarity, we repurchased an additional $4 million worth of shares in the first week of the second quarter, which was still under the prior authorization, bringing our year-to-date repurchases to $200 million. 
As a reminder, while our long-term framework reflects share repurchases of $100 million to $200 million per year, the actual amount of shares we repurchased in any given year could be higher or lower than that range, just like any of the elements in our framework. 
Looking at key drivers of our earnings performance for the first quarter, we had sales leverage from our positive same-restaurant sales of 1.3%; a favorable commodities environment resulting in approximately 1.5% deflation in food and beverage expense; continued progress leveraging our scale to achieve cost savings throughout the P&L; and approximately 170 basis points of incremental restaurant rent expense and other taxes resulting from real estate transactions last year. Excluding these costs, the restaurant expense line would have been approximately 10 basis points favorable to last year. In addition, below the restaurant level EBITDA line, we had depreciation and interest expense savings related to the real estate transactions; a planned gain of approximately $8 million, primarily related to the sale and closure of 1 Bahama Breeze restaurant. This transitional occurred in the first month of the fiscal quarter and was contemplated in the full fiscal 2017 earnings outlook we provided in June. 
And legal expenses that were unfavorable to our expectations by approximately $3 million, along with $2 million of support center rent expense and other taxes related to the sale leaseback. Excluding these expenses, SG&A as a percent of total sales would have been 40 basis points favorable to last year's adjusted G&A expense. 
Turning to segment performance. As a reminder, due to the real estate transactions last year, segment profit for the quarter include incremental rent and other tax expense of $29 million. The benefits of lower depreciation and interest savings are not recognized in segment profit. 
Olive Garden segment profit margin of 19.4% was 90 basis points lower than last year for the quarter as additional rent drove 230 basis points of margin unfavorability versus last year. Excluding the incremental rent, Olive Garden segment profit margin was 140 [ph] basis points higher than last year. LongHorn Steakhouse continues to strengthen its business model, improving segment profit margin by 70 basis points this quarter to 15.6%, even with a headwind of 150 basis points related to additional rents expenses. 
Excluding the incremental rent, segment profit margin increased 220 basis points at LongHorn. Segment profit margin declined 90 basis points to 14.8% in our Fine Dining segment. Although margins were lowered to the negative same-restaurant sales in the quarter, they were flat when excluding incremental rent expense and preopening costs, primarily related to 2 new Capital Grille openings in the quarter. 
Our Other Business segment profit margins were down 10 basis points on a year-over-year basis. As additional rents drove 60 basis points of margin unfavorability versus last year. Excluding the incremental rent, segment profit margin at our Other Business was 50 basis points higher than last year. 
Turning to our annual outlook. We increased our fiscal 2017 annual earnings per share range to be between $3.87 to $3.97 from our previous $3.80 to $3.90. This reflects an updated diluted average share count for the year of approximately 126 million shares, primarily as a result of higher-than-anticipated share repurchases in the first quarter as we took advantage of volatility in our stock price. 
All other aspects of our fiscal 2017 outlook remain unchanged, including our same-restaurant sales growth outlook of between 1% and 2%. And while we don't provide specific quarterly guidance, I do want to remind you of a few timing related factors that impact our quarter-to-quarter performance and comparisons to the prior year, specifically in the second quarter. 
First, in November, we will [ph] the completion of our real estate transaction last year. As such, we will incur approximately 2/3 of the incremental quarterly rent and depreciation impact we've been experiencing. However, we will have essentially a full quarters of interest savings relative to last year as most of the debt reduction related to our real estate transactions didn't occur until early in last year's third quarter. 
Additionally, the G&A expense in the second quarter of last year was abnormally low due to favorable legal settlement of approximately $13 million that we do not expect to recur. 
Finally, this favorable settlement was partially offset by approximately $8 million in asset impairments in the second quarter of last year, which is reported on the impairments line of our financial statements. 
As Gene mentioned, we are confident we have the right strategies in place. This is clearly evident in our sales outperformance versus the industry, while our teams continue to better manage their businesses and leverage Darden's scale to improve profitability. 
We continue to believe the ardent represents an attractive investment given our strong cash flow generation, our investment-grade credit rating with a compelling dividend yield, which is 3.65% based on yesterday's closing price; and as we laid out in our long-term framework, our expectations for 10% to 15% total shareholder return overtime. 
And with that, I will turn it over to Gene for some closing remarks.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick. And I was informed that I may have a problem with my microphone as I opened, so I want to summarize my opening comments before I close. Overall, I'm very pleased with our overall performance and the progress we have made against and strategi
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick. And I was informed that I may have a problem with my microphone as I opened, so I want to summarize my opening comments before I close. Overall, I'm very pleased with our overall performance and the progress we have made against and strategic initiatives in the quarter. Total sales and continuing operations are $1.7 billion, an increase of 1.6%. Same-restaurant sales grew 1.3%, outperforming the industry benchmarks, excluding Darden, by 340 basis points; and earnings per share were $0.88, an increase of 29.4% from last year's adjusted diluted net earnings. 
So overall, Q1 was a good quarter for us. Our strategies are working. We continue to grow share, improve margins and make meaningful investments in our business while returning capital to shareholders. It was also an important time of the year for us as we held our annual leadership conferences for each business. 
These conferences allow us to get in front of every general manager and managing partner across our 1,539 restaurants to align our plans for the year and generate a lot of excitement. 
For me personally, aside from being in our restaurants day to day, it's one of the things I enjoy most about my job. It's a great chance to engage with our leaders and listen to those closest to the action. It also confirm for me that our results during the people culture is truly what sets us apart. 
Our restaurant teams and our restaurant support center staff are the best in the business, and I take great pride in the fact that our team member turnover continues to be flat year-over-year, which reflects our compelling employment proposition. So I'll close by saying, thank you to our team members for their heart of everything we'll do. 
And now we'll open it up for questions.

componenttext: Yes, I think that's true. I think that we're also having some more success with our add-on sales and other things that we're doing. headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Brett Levy, Deutsche Bank.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you please give us a little bit of incrementally on what you're thinking about the competitive landscape. Why Olive Garden performed somewhat better than the others and really why -- where you saw the pockets of softness across the other brands, wheth
componenttext: Can you please give us a little bit of incrementally on what you're thinking about the competitive landscape. Why Olive Garden performed somewhat better than the others and really why -- where you saw the pockets of softness across the other brands, whether it be on the value, the premium side and regionality?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think I'd start. Let me start pretty broad, Brett, and then I'll fit down into our brands. I think the consumer environment is -- it continues to be difficult. I think there's a lot of choices the consumer has with their discretionary income, and I thin
componenttext: I think I'd start. Let me start pretty broad, Brett, and then I'll fit down into our brands. I think the consumer environment is -- it continues to be difficult. I think there's a lot of choices the consumer has with their discretionary income, and I think the restaurants are competing against a lot of those other choices, not just restaurants. I think restaurants today have to stay -- they have to stay relevant and they need to continue to invest in the experience. And I believe that this quarter of outperformance has less to do with what we did this quarter, but more to do we've done over the last 2 years to improve the overall experience in Olive Garden. And we've been on this plan now for almost 3 years since Dave George has been involved and everything cumulatively adding -- is adding up to our competitive advantage that we have in Olive Garden, which is value. And I think our advertising is relevant. I think most importantly, we're running better restaurants today than we were in the past and as you all know, this is a momentum business, and I think this business has that momentum right now. When I look at may be what you call weaknesses in the Other Business, somewhat I want to use that word, our business has performed well. We have big gaps in the marketplace. And I think LongHorn had a really good quarter. When we look at LongHorn, we'll give you segment earnings now, when you to look at that number, the overall performance of that business is up. We needed that business to contribute more from an earnings standpoint. We're getting that, and I'm pleased with it had. And when you look at -- I'll give you a little bit of color just based on geographic, Texas is still -- continues to be an area where we struggle. Obviously, Olive Garden continues to hold its own in Texas, but the momentum is split in there too.

componenttext: No, I'm not going to -- I'm really not going to share the mix for competitive reasons. Let me say that we've identified convenience as a huge opportunity. We've demonstrated that we've been able to pull that lever, take out -- altogether, it's about 50% -- up 50% over the last 3 years. What I will say is we have momentum in the catering and delivery space, but I'm not going to break down the components of our To Go for competitive reasons.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just 1 more then on LongHorn. Can you talk about what you're doing competitively? It seem like the [ph] coupons picked up during the quarter, again, maybe that's seasonal or I don't know if you were getting a little bit more aggressive perhaps t
componenttext: Okay. And just 1 more then on LongHorn. Can you talk about what you're doing competitively? It seem like the [ph] coupons picked up during the quarter, again, maybe that's seasonal or I don't know if you were getting a little bit more aggressive perhaps than you had been in the past couple of quarters.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me address that because, I think, this is a strategy that we're implementing, and we're executing this holistic marketing strategy and looking at all the tools we have available to us. As part of that, we've increased our digital spending in conjuncti
componenttext: Let me address that because, I think, this is a strategy that we're implementing, and we're executing this holistic marketing strategy and looking at all the tools we have available to us. As part of that, we've increased our digital spending in conjunction with our promotional strategy, which is really less broadscale discounting. And while using more targeted incentives to create value. And you can see the result of that as a look at our check average over time. We're not giving up check average as we shift incentives from freestanding inserts to digital. Digital is a much more cost-effective way to reach your consumer. And so as you take the value away from these price points and promotions, which are deep in LongHorn over the years, and you shifted to a more of a targeted digital incentive, we think that that's a much better way to go after this, and I think that we can see it in our financial performance. I would also just say, the landscape on advertising and marketing is changing dramatically. And we are constantly trying to find new ways and using our data [ph] to analyze what is going on and what is the most cost-effective way to deliver the appropriate value to the right guest at the right time. We will continue to evolve this over the next probably 24 to 36 months as the environment continues to change.

componenttext: Our next question comes from David Tarantino.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gene, my question is about Olive Garden's relative performance versus the industry. And if I look at the past several quarters, it looks like you saw a very sharp acceleration in the middle 2 quarters of last year in terms of your relative performance. My
componenttext: Gene, my question is about Olive Garden's relative performance versus the industry. And if I look at the past several quarters, it looks like you saw a very sharp acceleration in the middle 2 quarters of last year in terms of your relative performance. My question is really about your degree of confidence in sustaining the type of relative performance you've been seeing in the upcoming quarters given how difficult the comparisons are starting to get. And then I have a brief follow-up.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's pretty tough question, David. We think that -- we think we're doing the right things. We think we're starting with focus on the basics of the operation. I'm really impressed with Dan Carion, our head of operations, and what he's done with that team
componenttext: That's pretty tough question, David. We think that -- we think we're doing the right things. We think we're starting with focus on the basics of the operation. I'm really impressed with Dan Carion, our head of operations, and what he's done with that team to keep them motivated on trying to improve. Our guest feedback is at its highest levels ever. We think that our promotional strategy moving forward is sound. But do I feel confident that we're going to continue to outperform with the levels we've outperformed? I'm not sure. We're going to do the best we can, but I can't predict that. I think, we've got a good plan. I think we've done our work over the last few years and we'll continue to do our work and so I think we are well positioned, but those are big hurdles to get over.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then the quick follow-up, Gene, are you assuming that the industry trends that are a little better than they have been recently or are you assuming more of the same as you look at the balance of the fiscal year? And then maybe the second part o
componenttext: Great. And then the quick follow-up, Gene, are you assuming that the industry trends that are a little better than they have been recently or are you assuming more of the same as you look at the balance of the fiscal year? And then maybe the second part of the question is whether what are the things needed for the industry trends to get better than what we're seeing recently?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think there's a lot in that question, David, that I would say that as we think about industry, we're preparing -- we prepare our plans. We assume the industry is going to stay where the industry is going to stay. We're not assuming that the industr
componenttext: Yes, I think there's a lot in that question, David, that I would say that as we think about industry, we're preparing -- we prepare our plans. We assume the industry is going to stay where the industry is going to stay. We're not assuming that the industry is going to get a whole lot better. I wouldn't say that my message to our teams of us focus on what we control our great restaurants and delivering great food service and atmosphere. I think there some real uncertainly in the near term here, but that's going to pass. And from a consumer standpoint, I think, we're focused on the long-term. When you think about what's is going to take to move the whole industry, I don't know. I still look at there's a lot of great brands out there doing great things, growing sales and growing new restaurants and same-restaurant sales. I think they're well positioned. They've got good value equations. I'm hoping that some more inventory will come out of the system. We've seen some big announcements of closures lately. And I also think there's other -- as you drive down the road, I'm starting -- you're starting to see more restaurants close. You also see more restaurants open. But we could use some inventory to come out work that was helpful.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Sara Senatore, Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Sara Senatore, Bernstein.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is actually [indiscernible] representing Sara Senatore. A question on LongHorn, a lot of the conversation has been focused on getting a certain mix of profitable customers. Now that you've had a bit of time to asses the data and the P&L and kind of w
componenttext: This is actually [indiscernible] representing Sara Senatore. A question on LongHorn, a lot of the conversation has been focused on getting a certain mix of profitable customers. Now that you've had a bit of time to asses the data and the P&L and kind of work on the strategy, has the profitability mix responded in the way that you expect it to? And if prices were to persist, does the strategy still make sense?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we're thrilled with the performance LongHorn. Profitability has come back to historic norms. We've had 14 consecutive quarters of same-restaurant sales growth, significant outperformance over that time period, over the industry. So we've take
componenttext: Yes, I think we're thrilled with the performance LongHorn. Profitability has come back to historic norms. We've had 14 consecutive quarters of same-restaurant sales growth, significant outperformance over that time period, over the industry. So we've taken a lot of share. And so we feel good about where we're at, at this point in time. We'll continue to make investments. We have made yesterday, we've made some huge investments into our business in LongHorn. We've actually went back and increased the size of a couple of our stakes that we felt we needed to make that investment to get the quality where we need to be. We've improved our whole salad yesterday. So we're making investments in that business.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and a quick follow-up. Could you update us on your commodity outlook and if you're still expecting return inflation after this quarter? And on a similar note, what that means for price competition within the context of this environment.
componenttext: Okay, and a quick follow-up. Could you update us on your commodity outlook and if you're still expecting return inflation after this quarter? And on a similar note, what that means for price competition within the context of this environment.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I heard the commodity outlook question. I didn't hear the second part of your question. Can you repeat that?
componenttext: I heard the commodity outlook question. I didn't hear the second part of your question. Can you repeat that?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was asking if you can update us on the commodity outlook and if you're still expecting a return to inflation after this quarter? And if you could talk about what that means for price competition.
componenttext: I was asking if you can update us on the commodity outlook and if you're still expecting a return to inflation after this quarter? And if you could talk about what that means for price competition.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so we still expect commodities to inflate in the back half of the year more towards the fourth quarter. But we do expect commodities to be flat to low single digits unfavorable for the year. And as I said, this quarter, we were -- we had 150 basis p
componenttext: Okay, so we still expect commodities to inflate in the back half of the year more towards the fourth quarter. But we do expect commodities to be flat to low single digits unfavorable for the year. And as I said, this quarter, we were -- we had 150 basis points of commodity deflation. So you would see we had some inflation in the back half of the year. What does that mean to pricing? We still believe that we have the pricing strategy that's correct for us. Overall -- well, I‚Äôm sorry, and overall inflation for us we include labor and other things. There's still going to be 1.5% to 2%. So even though commodities are down in the beginning of the year and they're inflating the back half, overall for the year, we expect total inflation of 1.5% to 2%. As that relates to pricing, as we said, we expect to be in the low end of our 1% to 2% pricing this year. Olive Garden has taken their pricing action for the year already and LongHorn just did this week -- or earlier this month, I‚Äôm sorry. We do expect to do much more with pricing for the rest of the year unless something dramatically changes.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Will,
componenttext: Our next question comes from Will,

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is actually Billy on for Will. Wanted to ask on labor line. You'd mentioned again last quarter, the labor market remains tight across many of your markets. Do you have any updated thoughts that might helpful for us and should we still be thinking abo
componenttext: This is actually Billy on for Will. Wanted to ask on labor line. You'd mentioned again last quarter, the labor market remains tight across many of your markets. Do you have any updated thoughts that might helpful for us and should we still be thinking about that 2.5% to 3% wage inflation as appropriate given headed into this new calendar year?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a good question. I think that your 3% assumption for wage rate in the back half the year is probably the right assumption. The market continues to tighten and as I said in my prepared remarks, that we're holding turnover flat year-over-year. We'
componenttext: Yes, it's a good question. I think that your 3% assumption for wage rate in the back half the year is probably the right assumption. The market continues to tighten and as I said in my prepared remarks, that we're holding turnover flat year-over-year. We've got a strong employment proposition. Our people like what we do. So we're a place people want to work. So we'll continue to monitor the environment. We've changed some of our processes and procedures around hiring to help enable our restaurant managers to do a better job. And most importantly, we'll continue to look for ways to improve productivity at the restaurant level. I've said it for 2 years now, simplicity is a key to success in this business. We've made this businesses too complicated and we can get productivity enhancements as we simplify.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then just 1 more if I could, kind of taking a step back. I wanted to ask on possible acquisition opportunities. Do you guys have updated thoughts here lately as we've seen valuation come in across the space. Your balance sheet seems to
componenttext: That's helpful. And then just 1 more if I could, kind of taking a step back. I wanted to ask on possible acquisition opportunities. Do you guys have updated thoughts here lately as we've seen valuation come in across the space. Your balance sheet seems to be in a good place. So I guess is there any reason why something like that would be off the table with a good opportunity presented itself.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as I said, in the past, the management team and the board will regularly evaluate all the alternatives open to us to achieve our financial goals and we will continue do that. I'm not going to make any further comment in that.
componenttext: Well, as I said, in the past, the management team and the board will regularly evaluate all the alternatives open to us to achieve our financial goals and we will continue do that. I'm not going to make any further comment in that.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brian -- we have David Palmer, RBC.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brian -- we have David Palmer, RBC.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gene, first, a follow-up on Joe's question earlier, last quarter, the catering mix was a little under 11%. Are you updating that number? Can you give that number for the quarter?
componenttext: Gene, first, a follow-up on Joe's question earlier, last quarter, the catering mix was a little under 11%. Are you updating that number? Can you give that number for the quarter?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, total takeout was 11%. It was 11% of the business.
componenttext: Yes, total takeout was 11%. It was 11% of the business.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the discount that I was getting on our list I know where simple 1 that we're seeing the online orders that was being marketed at 20% discount versus the traditional pricing. It seems like an important initiative for Olive Garden to get into that habit
componenttext: And the discount that I was getting on our list I know where simple 1 that we're seeing the online orders that was being marketed at 20% discount versus the traditional pricing. It seems like an important initiative for Olive Garden to get into that habit, at least for takeout. Can you maybe walk us through the rational doing discounts like that, perhaps, it just makes sense on a mix basis given the labor and other. And maybe there's a growing base of web marketing that you can get from that? And then if I could squeeze 1 more in. Is online ordering of delivery for individual orders in your future and how [ph] could that be?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me deal with the first 1 and hopefully I remember the second 1. We believe it is important to move as many people as we possibly can over to online ordering. We've talked about the importance of that because the average check is much higher when someo
componenttext: Let me deal with the first 1 and hopefully I remember the second 1. We believe it is important to move as many people as we possibly can over to online ordering. We've talked about the importance of that because the average check is much higher when someone orders online, and we can prompt them through that order. But secondarily, from an operations standpoint, it's really important to not have -- if we can move people off the phone taking orders to serving guests in the restaurant, that's really helpful. And when you think about we have a To Go specialist 1, 2 or 3 and they're on the phone taking an order and there's a guest in front of them, the priority becomes the guest infront of them, not the person of the phone. So we feel like the service experience is a lot better as we move people to online, and we will continue to incentivize people to get into that and to get into that habit, and we believe it's 20% discount to do that. It's well worth it until we can change the behavior. The second question was individual or delivery, yes, we will continue, we are monitoring what is going on in that space. We are intimately involved with the big players that are in that space. They need us. We need them. We're going to proceed with caution. However, individual delivery orders are coming in the future somehow, someway. We just don't know who's going to be our partner, what the economics are going to be at this time.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from [ph].
componenttext: Our next question comes from [ph].

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Another question on the To Go business. As you started to move people onto a digital platform and have a little bit better tracking of who's ordering what. Do you have any numbers around frequency you'd be willing to share or any suggestion that people ar
componenttext: Another question on the To Go business. As you started to move people onto a digital platform and have a little bit better tracking of who's ordering what. Do you have any numbers around frequency you'd be willing to share or any suggestion that people are using large order delivery, large order delivery or large order takeout caught as almost a whole meal replacement option versus a catering occasion dlocation?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean I'm not going to get into a whole lot of detail, again, for competitive reasons. But they are using it for all different occasions. They're using it as a whole meal replacement. They're using that -- catering is a big word but you've got a min
componenttext: Yes, I mean I'm not going to get into a whole lot of detail, again, for competitive reasons. But they are using it for all different occasions. They're using it as a whole meal replacement. They're using that -- catering is a big word but you've got a minimum of $125 I believe on the Olive Garden takeout. It's something family meal if it's a large family. So it's being used for all sorts of occasion. I would tell you that the satisfaction rate is incredibly high for anybody that uses these services. Obviously, we're trying to monitor every single event trying to get feedback from the consumer. But right now, the consumer feedback is extremely, extremely high and they're very satisfied.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brian Bittner, Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brian Bittner, Oppenheimer.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the financial stuff. What's your calculated debt-to-EBITDA ratio today? And how does that relate to your targeted range? And if it's below your targeted range, could you deep into this low interest revolver you have, I think you have $750 million
componenttext: Just on the financial stuff. What's your calculated debt-to-EBITDA ratio today? And how does that relate to your targeted range? And if it's below your targeted range, could you deep into this low interest revolver you have, I think you have $750 million of untapped availability there. Could you dip into that to help these repurchases?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Brian, it's Rick. Our debt-to-EBITDA ratio right now is slightly under 2% and our long-term framework is 2 to 2.5. We do have a $750 million revolver. That doesn't mean that we're going to deep into. We'll continue to work with the board in figuring
componenttext: Hey, Brian, it's Rick. Our debt-to-EBITDA ratio right now is slightly under 2% and our long-term framework is 2 to 2.5. We do have a $750 million revolver. That doesn't mean that we're going to deep into. We'll continue to work with the board in figuring out what the best use of our capital is. If the stock race becomes volatile, we'll take advantage of that but that's probably about the sports with go on talking about how much we're going to buyback.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just going back to this To Go business, I mean, I think, it's probably one of the main incremental drivers to your outperformance against the industry and just still trying to fully understand what it is that you saw far apart in this use of you
componenttext: Okay. And just going back to this To Go business, I mean, I think, it's probably one of the main incremental drivers to your outperformance against the industry and just still trying to fully understand what it is that you saw far apart in this use of your business relative to your competitors? Obviously, the food a person be more affordable than others. But if you could just maybe it's a little bit more on what it is that you're driving -- you're doing to drive the incrementality there and what setting you apart in the To Go business versus your peers?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, you hit on the one of the most important ones, which is the food travel is really well. But, I think, it's also important to know that Olive Garden is under-indexed on Italian takeout for a long time. And so we think it was a huge opportunity for
componenttext: I think, you hit on the one of the most important ones, which is the food travel is really well. But, I think, it's also important to know that Olive Garden is under-indexed on Italian takeout for a long time. And so we think it was a huge opportunity for us to really promote and make people aware of what's available, and I think we're still -- we're scratching the surface on how we market this and I think the opportunity is large. When you think about -- even if we look at our other businesses and what the takeout opportunities are, they're not as great. I mean, Olive Garden, because of the food, I mean you can do a pan of [ph] you can do a pan of fettuccine alfredo. I mean, the cuisine lends itself to our takeout-type event. And so I think that's part of why we're having so much success there. We've got food, we under-indexed, I think, we're marketing it very effectively and we've got a consumer that wants it. The consumer wants that convenience.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: As you go forward and continue to talk to us about To Go, are you just -- is catering going to be lumped into the To Go conversation? Are those all going to be talked about as one?
componenttext: As you go forward and continue to talk to us about To Go, are you just -- is catering going to be lumped into the To Go conversation? Are those all going to be talked about as one?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. They are -- I really want to real this in for competitive reasons.
componenttext: Yes. They are -- I really want to real this in for competitive reasons.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Matthew DiFrisco, Guggenheim Securities.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Matthew DiFrisco, Guggenheim Securities.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a question about the other side of the outperformance. I guess, if you look both brand seems to have both LongHorn and Olive Garden seems to have outperformed roughly about 200 basis points if you wipe away the benefit that you're getting from the
componenttext: I have a question about the other side of the outperformance. I guess, if you look both brand seems to have both LongHorn and Olive Garden seems to have outperformed roughly about 200 basis points if you wipe away the benefit that you're getting from the growth, the 20% growth in takeout and catering. So I guess is that a reflection of not only the value, but is that also a reflection of diner. If you could sort of talk about what you're seeing across the industry, both your brands have historically, indexed a little bit more towards dinner some of your Casual Dining peer group. So I'm curious if the competition seems to be a lot heavier that you're seeing at the lunch daypart?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually we're seeing some decent growth at Olive Garden for lunch. I think if you go to an Olive Garden, you look at our lunch menu, there's only 5 or 6 price points on the front of that menu for the bottom part and they're all below 9 99 in most parts o
componenttext: Actually we're seeing some decent growth at Olive Garden for lunch. I think if you go to an Olive Garden, you look at our lunch menu, there's only 5 or 6 price points on the front of that menu for the bottom part and they're all below 9 99 in most parts of the country. So we've some good growth there at lunch. Dinner remain remains strong. I hate to keep pivoting back to this. I know that you guys don't like hear it but we're so focused on improving the restaurant visit for the guests of each individual restaurant. Operation is driving some of this growth and I can't emphasize that enough. This is a very difficult business to execute at a broad level. And we're -- we've done a great job focusing our teams on that and I think what's driving growth.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. I guess also can you just talk a little bit about as far as I look at the margin side, when do we get to the point or are we at the point where takeout these across the board sort of being agnostic to whether it's a order pickup or catering?
componenttext: That's great. I guess also can you just talk a little bit about as far as I look at the margin side, when do we get to the point or are we at the point where takeout these across the board sort of being agnostic to whether it's a order pickup or catering? Is it a higher margin than your in-store visit even with the potential discounting or marketing needed to try the business? Are we seeing this as a positive flow through on the margins as well as the mix effect?

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Matt, this is Rick. We still think our margins are neutral to what our in restaurants are because a lot of it is because of the alcohol and the other beverage you can sell in the restaurant. Even though we have a higher check in our To Go business, w
componenttext: Yes, Matt, this is Rick. We still think our margins are neutral to what our in restaurants are because a lot of it is because of the alcohol and the other beverage you can sell in the restaurant. Even though we have a higher check in our To Go business, we've got a lower margin on the food than on the alcohol.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just a last follow-up on that. Where do you stand as far as testing across some markets potentially delivery with some third parties?
componenttext: And then just a last follow-up on that. Where do you stand as far as testing across some markets potentially delivery with some third parties?

componenttextpreview: Yes, we're testing, we're looking at different third parties. We're not really wanting to talk about our testing process for competitive reasons. But as Gene mentioned, we're talking to a lot of these deliverers to see which one is going to win out.
componenttext: Yes, we're testing, we're looking at different third parties. We're not really wanting to talk about our testing process for competitive reasons. But as Gene mentioned, we're talking to a lot of these deliverers to see which one is going to win out.

headline: Darden Restaurants, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is it meaningful to the growth that you're seeing now across all stores that it's affecting year-over-year growth rate you're seeing in takeout and off-premise?
componenttext: Is it meaningful to the growth that you're seeing now across all stores that it's affecting year-over-year growth rate you're seeing in takeout and off-premise?
